items.title: Please remove (or make quieter) warning on decrypting with subkeys
items.body:
If i try to decrypt a message that was encrypted to a subkey, i run into a warning that seems superfluous.

It comes from `pgpy.PGPKey.decrypt()`:

```python
                warnings.warn("Message was encrypted with this key's subkey: {:s}. "
                              "Decrypting with that...".format(skid),
                              stacklevel=2)
```

I'm not convinced that this is a useful or meaningful warning.  Is there something that we want the calling application to do differently?  I'm inclined to suggest that we can just drop it entirely.

The [Python Logging HOWTO](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html) suggests:

> logging.info() (or logging.debug() for very detailed output for diagnostic purposes)
>
> warnings.warn() in library code if the issue is avoidable and the client application should be modified to eliminate the warning
> 
> logging.warning() if there is nothing the client application can do about the situation, but the event should still be noted

i'm inclined to say that this warrants at most `logging.info()`, but i'd really prefer as a user of the library to have it be `logging.debug()`, or just to remove the warning entirely.

I'm running into it in (for example) [adding decryption capabilities for `email-print-mime-structure`](https://bugs.debian.org/943959).  i have to shunt off stderr to get clean output, and shunting off stderr means i lose easy access to actual errors (when something goes legitimately wrong with the tool).

items.title: Signature verification fails where gnupg succeeds
items.body:
I've run across a signature that fails to validate in PGPy, for to me an unknown reason. The same signature is correctly verified by gpg. I'm attaching two different messages (ok.txt and fail.txt) with corresponding signatures (ok.txt.asc and fail.txt.asc), as well as the public key used to verify these (key.asc).

Note that gpg says they're both valid.
This succeeds: `$ gpg --verify fail_sig.txt fail.txt`

To reproduce it:
```python
from pgpy import PGPKey, PGPSignature

key, _ = PGPKey.from_file('key.txt')

with open('ok.txt') as f:
    message_ok = f.read()
signature_ok = PGPSignature.from_file('ok_sig.txt')

print(key.verify(message_ok, signature_ok))  # <SignatureVerification(True)>

with open('fail.txt') as f:
    message_fail = f.read()
signature_fail = PGPSignature.from_file('fail_sig.txt')

print(key.verify(message_fail, signature_fail))  # <SignatureVerification(False)>
```

Any insight into why this fails in PGPy would be greatly appreciated!
I've reproduced this both using the lastest commit from master, as well as 0.5.2.

[fail.txt](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/files/3789880/fail.txt)
[fail_sig.txt](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/files/3789897/fail_sig.txt)
[ok.txt](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/files/3789898/ok.txt)
[ok_sig.txt](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/files/3789900/ok_sig.txt)
[key.txt](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/files/3789901/key.txt)

items.title: Weirdness unlocking keys with unicode passphrases
items.body:
Hello!

Please excuse me if I have misunderstood something. I was hacking a bit on PGP passphrases, using your code as a reference, and I noticed these lines in `pgpy.packets.fields`:

    def derive_key(self, passphrase):
        ...
        hpass = passphrase.encode('latin-1')

That struck me as a bit odd, since the PGP spec says that strings should be considered UTF-8 unless otherwise stated. Your API docs are a little unclear about whether the passphrase passed to `PGPKey.unlock()` is a binary string or a unicode string... so I wrote a test script to test the possibilities:

```
#!/usr/bin/python
import pgpy
print('This is PGPy %s' % pgpy.__version__)

alice_passphrase = u'\xe6\xf0i'
alice_sec = """\
-----BEGIN PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----
Comment: From https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bre-openpgp-samples
Comment: Modified to add a unicode passphrase

lIYEXEcE6RYJKwYBBAHaRw8BAQdArjWwk3FAqyiFbFBKT4TzXcVBqPTB3gmzlC/U
b7O1u13+BwMCWaVJ2HbAEaX8G0ZZUe8lgNOgxpUYYB8ohUKfg1MoQ/jb4ZTbAjwQ
J8cSU9k7hXcydg1K/98XuO5gC9QqxFdv1J+d3fK+wQlG/3rn55fyBrQmQWxpY2Ug
TG92ZWxhY2UgPGFsaWNlQG9wZW5wZ3AuZXhhbXBsZT6IkAQTFggAOAIbAwULCQgH
AgYVCgkICwIEFgIDAQIeAQIXgBYhBOuFu1+jOnXhXpROY/IxVQxPR+OOBQJdpZ86
AAoJEPIxVQxPR+OO6SsA+gOccFKiA6awc6x32oayJmmBGc53Km9ub5C1dmq2H2u/
AP0dwMLS0L48cCw7s5OHVLVML1GImy9rAB8I9pBmh53yApyLBFxHBOkSCisGAQQB
l1UBBQEBB0BC/wYhratJPOCptcKkMNgyIpFWK0KzLbTfHewT356+IgMBCAf+BwMC
s+tXgtSCTLr8bogqwSptEHZYjmnHRepIYFPFJf0a0msNG4l0ZooL/l1IutzwGVwl
cXxZiHdAJJKDgiLRwnqhRAG1KK1I6kpgbY3TskugvYh4BBgWCAAgFiEE64W7X6M6
deFelE5j8jFVDE9H444FAlxHBOkCGwwACgkQ8jFVDE9H445Z0AEAxR1LOkyHMazU
7RGRY1BZtTNDydQ54P3A1uMTfNH7J9EBANtiq+1ZAo3gBAtPFUk3lfkBbJs+ef5Z
7VpMGFoZrzoB
=xCCz
-----END PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----
"""

(alice_key, _) = pgpy.PGPKey.from_blob(alice_sec)

# This is what a novice user would do, it fails:
try:
    with alice_key.unlock(alice_passphrase):
        alice_key.sign('this is a test')
except: 
    print('Unlocking with a normal unicode passphrase FAILS.')

# OK, lets convert that to string of bytes:
binary_passphrase = alice_passphrase.encode('utf-8')
try:
    with alice_key.unlock(alice_passphrase):
        alice_key.sign('this is a test')
except: 
    print('Unicode binary bytes also FAILS.')

# OK, let's get loco:
weird_passphrase = alice_passphrase.encode('utf-8').decode('latin-1')
with alice_key.unlock(weird_passphrase):
    alice_key.sign('this is a test')
    print('Unlocking with this weird construct works.')
```

This is the output I get on my machine:

```
$ python2 pgpy-test.py
This is PGPy 0.5.2
Unlocking with a normal unicode passphrase FAILS.
Unicode binary bytes also FAILS.
Unlocking with this weird construct works.
```

I think this is a bug. I doubt many consumers of the library will happen upon the magic incantation required to unlock a key that has a non-ascii passphrase.

(GnuPG happily accepted that passphrase and let me use the key, so I'm comfortable the key is well formed.)

I am not confident enough recommend a solution here - the "intuitive" API would be to accept unicode strings and decode them for people automatically. But that API might make it impossible to unlock keys with passphrases that weren't encoded as UTF-8. Accepting a string of bytes as the passphrase would be the most flexible approach, at the expense of some developer friendliness. The risk then becomes that app devs won't properly handle i18n either...

Anuway, I hope this helps!

```python
BAGXVQEFAQEHQEL/BiGtq0k84Km1wqQw2DIikVYrQrMttN8d7BPfnr4iAwEIBwAA
/3/xFPG6U17rhTuq+07gmEvaFYKfxRB6sgAYiW6TMTpQEK6IeAQYFggAIBYhBOuF
u1+jOnXhXpROY/IxVQxPR+OOBQJcRwTpAhsMAAoJEPIxVQxPR+OOWdABAMUdSzpM
hzGs1O0RkWNQWbUzQ8nUOeD9wNbjE3zR+yfRAQDbYqvtWQKN4AQLTxVJN5X5AWyb
Pnn+We1aTBhaGa86AQ==
=n8OM
-----END PGP PRIVATE KEY BLOCK-----
'''

(alice_key, _) = pgpy.PGPKey.from_blob(alice_sec)

# America/New_York during DST:
tz = datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=-4))
# 2019-10-20T09:18:11-0400
when = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(1571577491, tz)

pgpsig = alice_key.sign('this is a test', created=when)
roundtrip = pgpy.PGPSignature.from_blob(str(pgpsig))

if pgpsig.created.utctimetuple() != roundtrip.created.utctimetuple():
    print(f'original: {pgpsig.created.utctimetuple()}\nroundtrip: {roundtrip.created.utctimetuple()}')
    exit(1)
```

It currently fails, because the timezone gets confused.

items.title: unarmoring is brittle
items.body:
PGPy appears to be very good at generating standards-compliant ASCII-armored messages.

However, it is pretty brittle at reading subtly-non-standards-compliant messages.

In [some examples](https://gist.github.com/Valodim/59ae7c8a54abd7746412ae114c333721) there is a lacking checksum, or the lines of base64 are more than 76 characters long.

It might make sense to relax the constraints on import a little bit to deal with this kind of sloppiness.  In particular:

 * if no checksum is present, ignore its absence (it's not clear that the checksum provides much help on modern transmissions and networks)
 * limit the base64 lines to some larger but not outrageous limit (e.g. 1024 characters)

PGPy should continue to emit well-formed ASCII armor, of course!

items.title: please drop the "debian" branch, and rename it to "debian/master"
items.body:
[DEP-14](https://dep-team.pages.debian.net/deps/dep14/) recommends debian packaging to have dedicated branch naming within a `debian/` namespace.

Over on https://github.com/dkg/PGPy i've got a `debian/master` branch that shows the packaging cleanup i've done for 0.5.2-1, which i've just uploaded to debian unstable.  It would be great if you could drop the `debian` branch here (git tends to complain if a branch name is a strict prefix of a another slash-separated branch name), and import my `debian/master` branch into this main repo.

thanks for the 0.5.2 release, this is an exciting day for PGPy!

items.title: PGPKey.pubkey() should return self if this is a public key
items.body: it's not clear why `PGPKey.pubkey()` returns `None` if `self` is already a public key.  If it is a public key, why not just return itself?

items.title: Decrypt pgp data chunk by chunk
items.body:
Will there be an option to decrypt pgp data chunk by chunk?

The use case is, we have a service receiving large pgp file, chunk by chunk. Instead of landing the whole file to local disk (or memory), we want to decrypt the chunks on the fly and pass to 3rd party service.

We're looking for feature similar to how zlib library is decompressing gzip file:

```python
import zlib
decompressobj = zlib.decompressobj(32 + zlib.MAX_WBITS)
return decompressobj.decompress(data_chunk)
```

'decompressobj' consumes the incoming bytes, if the bytes are less than a zipped chunk, it'll return empty string and keep consuming the next piece of bytes.

So can pgp process the encrypted file in similar way?

items.title: Armorable should not automatically insert PGPy version information
items.body:
GnuPG [no longer publishes the version information by default](https://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gnupg-devel/2016-August/031424.html).  For a good summary of why this inclusion of metadata might not be a great idea, see [this post by ilf](https://lists.gnupg.org/pipermail/gnupg-devel/2016-August/031467.html).

It'd be great if PGPy's Armorable class didn't default its `ascii_headers` to a dictionary containing the same sort of metadata.

items.title: subkey revocation signature verification fails
items.body:
One of my authentication subkeys was revoked recently, according to GnuPG:

```
The following key was revoked on 2017-01-16 by RSA key 792152527B75921E Antoine Beaupré <anarcat@anarc.at>
sub  rsa2048/46DC033CAFD0FDF8
     created: 2012-07-24  revoked: 2017-01-16  usage: A   
```

So I should be able to verify this with PGPy:

```python
In [56]: k, _ = pgpy.PGPKey.from_file('anarcat.asc')
In [57]: k.verify(k, k.subkeys['46DC033CAFD0FDF8']._signatures[1])
Out[57]: <SignatureVerification(False)>   
```

Ooops. Maybe it's because i didn't use the right subject:

```python
In [58]: k.verify(k.subkeys['46DC033CAFD0FDF8'], k.subkeys['46DC033CAFD0FDF8']._signatures[1]) 
Out[58]: <SignatureVerification(False)> 
```

Nope. What happened here? Some more details about the signature found:

```python
In [67]: k.subkeys['46DC033CAFD0FDF8']._signatures[1].signer == k.fingerprint.keyid
Out[67]: True
In [68]: k.subkeys['46DC033CAFD0FDF8']._signatures[1].type
Out[68]: <SignatureType.SubkeyRevocation: 40>
```

So I was told this might be a bug by @Commod0re so I'm blindly documenting it here. :)

items.title: ed25519 support
items.body:
Hi!

I see that ed25519 support is missing from PGPy. Since it is a commonly used curve in GPG, I started looking into how it could be implemented here.

It seems the first problem is that support for that curve is missing from OpenSSL itself, as shown by https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/487. According to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/487#issuecomment-310086601, a patch was merged in june to add support in master, which should take some time to propagate everywhere. The two patches are https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/3585 and https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/3503 which seem to indicate the magic word may be `ED25519` but i'm not sure.

So I wonder if that could simply be implemented in PGPy's side with:

```patch
diff --git a/pgpy/_curves.py b/pgpy/_curves.py
index 9503075..8417d15 100644
--- a/pgpy/_curves.py
+++ b/pgpy/_curves.py
@@ -48,7 +48,13 @@ class BrainpoolP512R1(object):
     key_size = 512
 
 
+@utils.register_interface(ec.EllipticCurve)
+class Ed25519P256R1(object):
+    name = 'Ed25519'
+    key_size = 256
+
+
 # add these curves to the _CURVE_TYPES list
-for curve in [BrainpoolP256R1, BrainpoolP384R1, BrainpoolP512R1]:
+for curve in [BrainpoolP256R1, BrainpoolP384R1, BrainpoolP512R1, Ed25519P256R1]:
     if curve.name not in ec._CURVE_TYPES and curve.name in _openssl_get_supported_curves():
         ec._CURVE_TYPES[curve.name] = curve
```

would that make sense? or there are some fundamental things to change elsewhere in the code?

items.title: SignatureVerification.sigsubj.by is a keyid not PGPKey
items.body:
The `SignatureVerification` docstrings state that the `sigsubj.by` should be of type, `pgpy.PGPKey`, while in reality what comes out of `key.verify()` has `sigsubj.by` a keyid string.

        """
        A generator yielding namedtuples of all signatures that were successfully verified
        in the operation that returned this instance. The namedtuple has the following attributes:

        ``sigsubj.verified`` - ``bool`` of whether the signature verified successfully or not.

        ``sigsubj.by`` - the :py:obj:`~pgpy.PGPKey` that was used in this verify operation.

        ``sigsubj.signature`` - the :py:obj:`~pgpy.PGPSignature` that was verified.

        ``sigsubj.subject`` - the subject that was verified using the signature.
        """

items.body:
I encountered a strange bug:

```
----------------------------------------------------------------------

  File "/home/johny/gsoc/psf/mailman/PGPy/pgpy/decorators.py", line 125, in _action

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/contextlib.py", line 82, in __enter__

  File "/home/johny/gsoc/psf/mailman/PGPy/pgpy/decorators.py", line 92, in usage
    if self.flags & set(_key._get_key_flags(user)):
  File "/home/johny/gsoc/psf/mailman/PGPy/pgpy/pgp.py", line 1708, in _get_key_flags
    return next(self.self_signatures).key_flags
  File "/home/johny/gsoc/psf/mailman/PGPy/pgpy/pgp.py", line 1359, in self_signatures
    else (self.parent.fingerprint.keyid, SignatureType.Subkey_Binding)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'fingerprint'
----------------------------------------------------------------------
```
With keys generated like this:  https://gitlab.com/J08nY/mailman-pgp/blob/master/src/mailman_pgp/pgp/keygen.py

This all comes down to the pubkeys subkeys not having a proper `parent` attribute. While the original private keys subkeys have the `parent` attribute pointing at the private key.

I think the problem is around [pgp.py#L1320](https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/blob/master/pgpy/pgp.py#L1320) where the pubkeys subkeys are created and it's obvious they won't have any `parent` set because they have no way to know about the newly created parent.

```python
                # get the public half of each subkey
                for skid, subkey in self.subkeys.items():
                    pub.subkeys[skid] = subkey.pubkey
```

I think doing something like
```python
                # get the public half of each subkey
                for skid, subkey in self.subkeys.items():
                    pub.subkeys[skid] = subkey.pubkey
                    pub.subkeys[skid].parent = pub
```
where `pub` is the newly created public sibling.

items.title: PGPMessage does not export signatures if encrypted
items.body: Along #186, with If there are signatures on an encrypted message (i.e. encrypt-then-sign), they are not exported with the rest of the message. Although this is not necessarily the recommended order to do things in, it still constitutes a valid PGP message.

items.title: document exceptions that PGPKey.decrypt can raise
items.body:
It seems I forgot to document the exception(s) that PGPKey.decrypt can raise, and what conditions cause them to be raised. They are:


- if the message was not encrypted by this key, `PGPError` is raised
- if the symmetric key was encrypted using an asymmetric algorithm that PGPy does not (yet) support, `NotImplementedError` is raised
- if the decrypted symmetric key checksum is wrong, or if message decryption fails, `PGPDecryptionError` is rasised

items.title: PGPy does not calculate private key checksums correctly
items.body:
Using keys generated by PGPy I can encrypt using gpg without problems, but I'm unable to decrypt messages with gpg. I'm getting an error:
```
gpg: public key decryption failed: checksum error
gpg: decryption failed: secret key not available
```

To test it I'm using the following script:
https://gist.github.com/meskio/a9ccb19fa629e7bcf991cdea2018db26
It produces the same error with gpg 2.1 or gpg 1.4.

Am I doing something wrong? Or there is there an issue on the key generation/export of PGPy?

items.title: Investigate test suite heisenbug
items.body: Very occasionally the gpg_print test fixture fails to return data even though it should have, causing automated builds to fail. I'm not sure if this is a timing error or what, but it needs to be fixed

items.title: debian packaging
items.body:
Hi Michael!

I've put a debian branch at https://github.com/dkg/PGPy -- feel free to review it and pull it in and publish the packaging on your own debian branch if you like (i don't know how to make a github pull request to a non-existent branch).

I just uploaded the head of it to debian, which should put it in the NEW queue.  Given that we're in a freeze, it'll probably take a while to get out of the NEW queue, but i figure it's better to go ahead and start the process.  We can always tweak and improve the packaging as we go.

Let me know if you have any questions!

items.title: Error importing pgpy generated keys with gnupg
items.body:
when creating a new keypair with pgpy v0.4 (only with name attribute, not email, though this doesn't seem to matter), then export private and public keys to files, there are errors importing them with gnupg v1.1.18 into a keyring.

Here some cases tested:

- key generated with passphrase
 - key generated with subkey
     - import exported private key
         works
     - import exported public key
         `gpg: [don't know]: invalid packet (ctb=53)
          gpg: read_block: read error: Invalid packet
          gpg: import from '/tmp/F96AD179_wIyaJd.asc' failed: Invalid keyring`
          subkey is not imported
 - key generated without subkey
     - import exported private key
         works
     - import exported public key
         works

- key generated without passhrase
 - key generated with subkey
     - import exported private key
         `error sending to agent: Checksum error
          gpg: error building skey array: Checksum error`
     - import exported public key
         does not import subkey

 - key generated without subkey
     - import exported private key
         `error sending to agent: Checksum error`
     - import exported public key
         works

Unfortunately the message isn't interpreted correctly by PGPy because although it is able to find the subkeys, etc. PGPy determines that the message is unencrypted.  I'm not sure what I am doing wrong.  I had to play around for a while to get PGPy to read the message generated by openpgpjs.  It seems like openpgpjs created symmetric messages it might be interpreted correctly, but the assymetric message isn't.  What do you guys think?  I would like to work on this problem, but might need some guidance as to what to look for in debugging, etc.

items.title: NotImplementedError <class 'pgpy.packet.types.Opaque'> when creating PGPMessages from longer blobs
items.body:
I've run into a similar issue as reported here: https://github.com/SecurityInnovation/PGPy/issues/160.  I think it's might have different causes so I'm reporting it as a separate bug.

The bug is that I get the same `NotImplementedError` when I run `PGPMessage.from_blob()` on messages that are not very short.  For example:

items.title: NotImplementedError: <class 'pgpy.packet.types.Opaque'>
items.body:
I get an error when attempting to load a PGPMessage from a blob the method works fine in parse method where it takes a packet as an argument, but at the during the else statement it throws an error. I believe it results from this:

```
def parse(self, packet):
        unarmored = self.ascii_unarmor(packet)
        data = unarmored['body']

        if unarmored['magic'] is not None and unarmored['magic'] not in ['MESSAGE', 'SIGNATURE']:
            raise ValueError('Expected: MESSAGE. Got: {}'.format(str(unarmored['magic'])))

        if unarmored['headers'] is not None:
            self.ascii_headers = unarmored['headers']

        # cleartext signature
        if unarmored['magic'] == 'SIGNATURE':
            # the composition for this will be the 'cleartext' as a str,
            # followed by one or more signatures (each one loaded into a PGPSignature)
            self |= self.dash_unescape(unarmored['cleartext'])
            while len(data) > 0:
                pkt = Packet(data)
                if not isinstance(pkt, Signature):  # pragma: no cover
                    warnings.warn("Discarded unexpected packet: {:s}".format(pkt.__class__.__name__), stacklevel=2)
                    continue
                self |= PGPSignature() | pkt

        else:
            while len(data) > 0:
                self |= Packet(data)
```

It looks to me as if the bitwise or operation |= doesn't function right because the Packet class doesn't accept the data argument provided.  I don't really understand immediately what the result of the overall operation should be.  I'm not sure how to get this working immediately.

items.title: ZeroDivisionError - constants.py
items.body:
When forming a new public and private key together with a subkey and then password protecting the key like this:

```
key = pgpy.PGPKey.new(PubKeyAlgorithm.RSAEncryptOrSign, 4096)
pw = 'd71ien2318138kk3'

key.protect(pw, SymetricKeyAlgorithm.AES256, HashAlgorithim.SHA256)
```

Gives the ZeroDivisionError:

> line 354, in tune_count
>     ct = int(len(_hashtunedata) \* (_TIME / (end - start)))
> ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero

I believe this is because not a significant amount of time has occurred between the start and end time used in tune_count.  When I looked closer at the tune_count it looks like there was no difference in the start and end time on my system.  I attempted to change it into this:

```
start = time.time()
h = self.hasher
h.update(_hashtunedata)
sysRnd = SystemRandom()
time.sleep(sysRnd.uniform(0.0000001, 0.0000002))
end = time.time()
```

I feel like this might be somewhat system dependent.  Sometimes I get the error and sometimes I don't.  I thought it might be better to have somewhat a variable time based on SystemRandom to add some entropy into the process.

items.title: py3 text_to_bytes(unicode_string) results in mojibake
items.body:
https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojibake

In Python3, PGPMessage.new(unicode_string) munges the string even before any encryption happens.  This is because PGPObject.text_to_bytes() is munging the unicode.  This results in an undecodable byte string.

The currently Py3 workaround is to PGPMessage.new(unicode_bytearray).

This issue tracks fixing PGPMessage.new(unicode_string).

See #153 for STR tests.

items.title: Refactor byte conversion process to make nested serialization even more IO efficient
items.body:
After attending the talk on bytearrays at PyCon, I had an idea:
- Refactor the bytearray seralization steps out into a separate set of object methods (e.g. `__bytearray__`)
- Call that from `__bytes__`
- Now `__bytes__` should (ideally) only be called on the outermost level, which should reduce IO, as appending a bytearray to another bytearray is a much more efficient operation than converting to bytes, then back to a bigger bytearray

I don't necessarily expect this to be an insane improvement, but it should be measurable, so I plan to actually profile and benchmark the difference here as well.

Also, I think that doing this will help make the implementation of #139 a bit easier (and hopefully also more efficient than it might have been otherwise - small inefficiencies with IO in Python seem to compound very quickly as the amount of data being moved in those operations increases)

items.title: verifier.verify with a DSA key sometimes raises AssertionError and this is not caught
items.body:
starting at line 1833 in pgp.py:

``` python
                try:
                    verifier.verify()

                except InvalidSignature:
                    pass

                else:
                    verified = True
```

If the key is a DSA key, because of the way cryptography is written (at least with the version that this bug was found in), sometimes an AssertionError is raised instead of InvalidSignature, it's not being caught.

It should be handled probably the same as InvalidSignature. I should also probably let the cryptography guys know that that is bad behavior.

items.title: string-formatting UserID packets is breaking in some situations
items.body:
Take the following stripped key for example:

```
-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
Version: PGPy v0.3.0

mQGiBEFEnz8RBAC7LstGsKD7McXZgd58oN68KquARLBl6rjA2vdhwl77KkPPOr3O
YeSBH/voUsqausJfDNuTNivOfwceDe50lbhq52ODj4Mx9Jg+4aHn9fmRkIk41i2J

VzACJLuZWHbDsPoJaNQjiFcEAKbUF1rMyjd1xJM7bZeXbs8c+ohUo/ywSI/OIr8n
OfUswy08tsCof1KU0JBGLBCn0lHAYkAAcSr2pQ+k/odwdLQSjgm/JcUbi2ll16Wy
7qFbUAUJ5xO+iP61vL3z4pJGcK1pMH6kBLA4CPBchJU/hh3f7vtX2oFdWw8tWqvm
m/W7BACE7h0p86OP2G3ZJBjNYNQTK1LFYa+3G0spsVi9wl+Ih49ImPbSsUc2CSMA
fDlGpYU8FuUKCgQnS3UZz6e0NwrHbZTHBy0ksRwT9jf7qSAEKEN2ECxfwR5i1dU+
Yi4owkqGPhTLAbwkYdZZMcqfGgTXbiU4uy8DzMH/VhqP5wxdwbQ7VWJ1bnR1IEFy
Y2hpdmUgQXV0b21hdGljIFNpZ25pbmcgS2V5IDxmdHBtYXN0ZXJAdWJ1bnR1LmNv
bT6IXgQTEQIAHgUCQUSfPwIbAwYLCQgHAwIDFQIDAxYCAQIeAQIXgAAKCRBAl26v
Q30FtSTNAJ9TwRBI9/dXHqsyx5LkWrPxyO2H7wCfXDY77HnwSK3tTqJzC4m6KuDd
Rhc=
=Z3fb
-----END PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
```

for reference, run through pgpdump:

```
% pgpdump stripped.asc
Old: Public Key Packet(tag 6)(418 bytes)
    Ver 4 - new
    Public key creation time - Sun Sep 12 12:10:55 PDT 2004
    Pub alg - DSA Digital Signature Algorithm(pub 17)
    DSA p(1024 bits) - ...
    DSA q(160 bits) - ...
    DSA g(1024 bits) - ...
    DSA y(1024 bits) - ...
Old: User ID Packet(tag 13)(59 bytes)
    User ID - Ubuntu Archive Automatic Signing Key <ftpmaster@ubuntu.com>
Old: Signature Packet(tag 2)(94 bytes)
    -snip-
```

The important part here is the User ID Packet. Now, we can see that PGPy has parsed it correctly, at least:

``` python
In [40]: k2.userids[0].name
Out[40]: 'Ubuntu Archive Automatic Signing Key'

In [41]: k2.userids[0].comment

In [42]: k2.userids[0].email
Out[42]: 'ftpmaster@ubuntu.com'
```

However, trying to use the string-formatting does not work as it ought to:

``` python
In [43]: "{}".format(k2.userids[0])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-43-65bf4aba81dd> in <module>()
----> 1 "{}".format(k2.userids[0])

PGPy/pgpy/pgp.py in __format__(self, format_spec)
    631     def __format__(self, format_spec):
    632         if self.is_uid:
--> 633             comment = six.u("") if self.comment == "" else six.u(" ({:s})").format(self.comment)
    634             email = six.u("") if self.email == "" else six.u(" <{:s}>").format(self.email)
    635             return six.u("{:s}{:s}{:s}").format(self.name, comment, email)

TypeError: non-empty format string passed to object.__format__
```

The problem, as it turns out, is a very simple one. I didn't pay enough attention to what I was doing, it would seem:

``` python
In [46]: k2.userids[0].comment == ""
Out[46]: False

In [47]: type(k2.userids[0].comment)
Out[47]: NoneType
```

The fix is very simple, but i'm listing four tasks for this issue:
- [x] Make sure that the regular expression in UserID.parse is consistent in how it assigns missing comment and email (i.e. `None` vs `""`)
- [x] Either change UserID.parse to assign "" instead of None, or change from `if self.comment == ""` to `if self.comment is None` and probably also `if self.email == ""` to `self.email is None`
- [ ] Coverate didn't cue me that this may not have been completely tested because I used the ternary operator to avoid the ugliness of chained `if`s. However, having those chained `if`s could have prevented this bug from making it past unit testing/ci, so I will change it.
- [ ] Ensure that the unit tests are actually testing all of the possible branches for `PGPUID.__format__`

items.title: Armorable.from_blob fails if the blob is a bytes object
items.body:
because it assumes it is a str, and this may not always be the case.

Probably the easiest fix would be to change:

``` python
def from_blob(cls, blob):
    obj = cls()
    po = obj.parse(bytearray(blob, 'latin-1'))
```

to

``` python
def from_blob(cls, blob):
    obj = cls()
    if isinstance(blob, six.binary_type):
        po = obj.parse(bytearray(blob))
    else:
        po = obj.parse(bytearray(blob, 'latin-1'))    
```

items.title: Message parsing

milestone.description:
The 0.3.0 branch represents a large refactoring of the code along with some API enhancements that are likely to break existing code that uses PGPy 0.2.x.

It also targets adding the following functionality:
 - [ ] inline signature verification
 - [ ] inline signing
 - [ ] Data encryption
 - [ ] Data decryption
 - [ ] Trust model

items.body:
Before it is possible to support signing/verifying inline signatures, or data encryption/decryption, `PGPMessage` must support the following message types:
- [x] Cleartext Signatures 
  
  Cleartext signatures are similar to Messages (the header magic is `SIGNED MESSAGE` rather than `MESSAGE`; this one has no tail, but has an ASCII-armored `SIGNATURE` at the end)
- OpenPGP Messages
  
  There are a few different kinds of messages, each defined by a packet composition as follows:
  - [x] Literal Message
    
    `[Literal Data Packet]`
  - [x] Compressed Message
    
    `[Compressed Data Packet]`
  - Signed Message
    - [x] `[Signature Packet, OpenPGP Message]`
    - [x] `[Signature Packet, One-Pass Signed Message]`
  - [x] One-Pass Signed Message
    - `[One-Pass Signature Packet, OpenPGP Message, Signature]`
      
      The One-Pass Signature/Signature act as a matched par that bracket their contents, such that multiple One-Pass signatures for the same message are nested within each other.
      I'll need to obtain/generate one to confirm this, but it appears that all such nested pairs only sign the message construct at the center, not the other one-pass signature pairs within.
  - [x] Encrypted Message
    - `[{Encrypted Data}]`
    - `[{ESK}[, {ESK} ...], {Encrypted Data}]`
    
    Encrypted Data is composed of either a Symmetrically-Encrypted Data Packet, or a Symmetrically-Encrypted & Integrity Protected Data Packet
    
    ESK is either a Public-Key Encrypted Session Key Packet or a Symmetric-Key Encrypted Session Key Packet

items.title: Backport bytearray speedup

milestone.description: Some additional bugfixes

items.body:
A super minor change to the main parse loop that results in ~160x speedup in packet parsing.

It's dead simple:

``` diff
--- a/pgpy/pgp.py
+++ b/pgpy/pgp.py
@@ -163,16 +163,15 @@
                 self.ascii_headers[key] = val

-            self.data = base64.b64decode(k[2].replace('\n', '').encode())
+            self.data = bytearray(base64.b64decode(k[2].replace('\n', '').encode()))
             self.crc = bytes_to_int(base64.b64decode(k[3].encode()))

             # verify CRC
             if self.crc != self.crc24():
                 raise Exception("Bad CRC")  # pragma: no cover

         # dump fields in all contained packets per RFC 4880, without using pgpdump
         if self.data != b'':
-            pos = 0
-            while pos < len(self.data):
+            while len(self.data) > 0:
-                pkt = Packet(self.data[pos:])
+                pkt = Packet(self.data)
-                pos += len(pkt.header.__bytes__()) + pkt.header.length
+                del self.data[:(len(pkt.header.__bytes__()) + pkt.header.length)]
                 self.packets.append(pkt)
```

Currently (0.2.1, 0.2.2), when trying to read a valid file path without proper permissions, it is handled incorrectly, and eventually generates a PGPError saying no ASCII was found.

items.title: Unit Test Overhaul

milestone.description:
The 0.3.0 branch represents a large refactoring of the code along with some API enhancements that are likely to break existing code that uses PGPy 0.2.x.

It also targets adding the following functionality:
 - [ ] inline signature verification
 - [ ] inline signing
 - [ ] Data encryption
 - [ ] Data decryption
 - [ ] Trust model

items.body:
It's that time again! Unit testing needs to be improved.

So, let's tighten up the test procedure again, shall we?

New testdata:
- Split some things up using gpgsplit:
  - Need at least one of each type of GPG packet
    - And one of each variant where there are multiple types of that packet
  - Also, let's split the primary key packet off of each of the private key blocks that have encrypted key material, since the only test involving them is successfully decrypting those
- Split some other things up more manually:
  - Need at least one of each type of the more complex packet fields
  - Need at least one of each type of signature subpacket
    - Need to test the critical bit flag as well
  - Need at least one of each type of user attribute subpacket
- Less whole key blocks
  - Probably only need one primary key for each type, and a subkey or two
- Signatures
  - Currently, all tests of signatures are against detached signatures of binary documents signed by all the different whole keys
  - This needs to change, to be more complete and robust:
    - Signatures of Binary Documents:
      - One detached signature per algorithm
      - One inline signature per algorithm
    - Other signature types:
      - Just one of each, plus whatever was signed, so the signature can also be verified
- Messages
  - Currently, messages are not supported at all, but test material should be ready anyway.
  - So we need:
    - a signed message
    - an encrypted message
    - a compressed message
    - a multipart message

And an updated series of unit tests:
- Continue to test FileLoader
- Packet tests:
  - Test all subpackets
  - Test all packets
- Block Load Tests
  - Test loading all of the different kinds of ASCII armored blocks
  - Test loading GPG keyrings
  - Test expected attributes existence and functionality
  - Test ASCII armoring to export those things
- PGPKey tests
  - Load a key for each algorithm and test the following actions:
    - sign something
    - verify a signature
    - encrypt something (eventually; once that is actually implemented)
    - decrypt something (eventually; once that is actually implemented)
- PGPKeyring tests
  - Load a GPG keyring
  - Test key selection and context management
  - Test expected attributes existence and functionality
  - Test key export
